results.title: The Daily routine (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Charles Silverman, Thomas Nielson, A High and Self Production
results.brief_description: Shows how organising the routine of the day in the primary school aids teachers’ curriculum and cognitive goals, and how a consistent routine allows children to predict the sequence of events, experience different time lengths and the concepts of beginning, middle and end. The film also illustrates how activities and drama during specific times of the day reinforce cognitive goals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Silverman, Thomas Nielson, A High and Self Production

results.title: Daily miracle
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how the newspaper “The West Australian” is set up and printed. The film shows all stages of production, from setting of type which is then checked in the reading room to the final printing on rolls which contain over 120 miles of newsprint. Demonstrates how a big newspaper works, and its reliance on other world sources of news.

results.title: Daily life of the Bozo people
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: A documentary account of a typical day for the Bozo tribe in Mali, West Africa. Environmental demands are met through a classic division of labour determined in large part by the annual fluctuations of the River Niger. Shows the people as they wash, weave, fish, cook and eat. Without narration - natural sounds only.
results.description: A documentary account of a typical day for the Bozo tribe in Mali, West Africa. results.title: Daily bread
results.brief_description: Although Britain grows grain, most of the flour needed to make the bread which feeds the people of the British Isles is imported from overseas. This film follows the processes of manufacture from the time that the flour is unloaded in the ports until it leaves the baker’s van in the delivery-man’s basket.

results.title: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan
results.brief_description: Traces the early history of photography, concentrating on the achievements of Joseph Niepce, who in 1822 invented the first permanent photograph. Louis Daguerre, who in 1838, developed a process for recording photographs on polished metal plates is shown with other innovators in the field.
results.title_for_label: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan

results.title: Czechoslovakia: land and people
results.brief_description: Czechoslovakia is a country of two parts: Slovakia, a rugged mountainous land, and the Czech lands, a rich farming region with many industrial cities. With historical perspective we see the two regions as part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, then as a democracy after World War I, and finally as a Communist state.

results.title: Cyclone Tracy
results.creator_credit: Chris Noonan, Peter Johnson, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description: At Christmas 1974, Darwin was hit by Cyclone Tracy, which left a train of almost inconceivable destruction. This film shows the damage wrought, and people’s reactions during and after the cyclone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Noonan, Peter Johnson, Timothy Read and Film Australia

results.title: Cyclone approaching
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Indicates the counter-disaster operations initiated by the civil defence organizations and the simple safety procedures which should be followed by the community in general. Uses Cyclone Tracy as an example and includes graphic scenes depicting the type of devastation that cyclones can produce.

results.title: Cycle tour of Tasmania
results.brief_description: Captures the loneliness of the long distance cyclist. Covers one of the world’s most gruelling cycle races which circles the island. The aim of the film is to attract the premier amateur cycling countries to enter this event.
